Class ec.util.GenericHashtable 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----ec.util.GenericHashtable
public abstract class GenericHashtable
extends Object
This is a better Hashtable than the normal java.util one. It is abstract so as to be able to have its particular hashing and equality checks defined by subclasses. The two provided concrete versions are IdentityHashTable--based on == and System.identityHashCode()--and EqualsHashTable--based on Object.equals() and Object.hashCode().

See Also:
EqualsHashtable, IdentityHashtable

GenericHashtable()
Constructs a new, empty Hashtable, with a reasonable set of defaults.

Gets the object in the table for the key that is equal to the given one, as defined by the equality function of the table, or null if there is no such object.

Return an enumeration of the keys in the set.

This method must be overridden by subclasses to define the way to compare two keys for equality.

GenericHashtable 
 public GenericHashtable(int initialCapacity,
                         double loadFactor,
                         int maxProbes)
Construct a new, empty Hashtable, with the specified parameters.

Parameters:
initialCapacity - the initial number of elements the table should be prepared to hold
loadFactor - a number between 0.0 (exclusive) and 1.0, defining the threshold for growing the table's underlying arrays.
maxProbes - the maximum number of probes into the table's underlying arrays to make. Larger numbers mean slower performance but better memory usage.
Throws: IllegalArgumentException
thrown if initialCapacity <= 0
Throws: IllegalArgumentException
thrown if loadFactor <= 0 or loadFactor > 1
Throws: IllegalArgumentException
thrown if maxProbes <= 0
GenericHashtable 
 public GenericHashtable()
Constructs a new, empty Hashtable, with a reasonable set of defaults.

size 
 public int size()
Get the number of elements in the table.

Returns:
the number of elements in the table.

 public boolean isEmpty()
Return true if the table contains no elements.

Returns:
true if the table contains no elements.

 public Enumeration elements()
Return an enumeration of the values in the table.

Returns:
the enumeration

 public Enumeration keys()
Return an enumeration of the keys in the set.

Returns:

containsKey 
 public boolean containsKey(Object key)
Returns true if the specified object is a key in the table, as defined by the equality function of the table.

Parameters:
value - the object to look for
Returns:
true if the key is in the table
Throws: NullPointerException
thrown if key == null
get 
 public Object get(Object key)
Gets the object in the table for the key that is equal to the given one, as defined by the equality function of the table, or null if there is no such object.

Parameters:
key - the object to look for
Returns:
nullOk; the value in the set, or null if there is no such object
Throws: NullPointerException
thrown if value == null
put 
 public Object put(Object key,
                   Object value)
Put the given key/value pair into the table. If the key is equivalent (according to the equal function) to a key already in the table, the key/value pair is replaced.

Parameters:
key - the key to place in the table
value - the value to place in the table
Returns:
nullOk; the old value in the table, or null if there was no such object
Throws: NullPointerException
thrown if key == null
Throws: NullPointerException
thrown if value == null
remove 
 public Object remove(Object key)
Removes the given key (or its equivalent, according to the equal function) from the table. This does nothing if the object is not actually a key in the table.

Parameters:
key - the key to remove
Returns:
nullOk; the old value in the table or null if there was no such key
Throws: NullPointerException
thrown if key == null
removeOne 
 public Object removeOne()
This removes and returns one element from the table. If there are no elements in the table, this returns null.

Returns:
nullOk; a value removed from the table or null if the table is empty
clear 
 public void clear()
This clears out the table so that it has no elements in it.

performEquals 
 public abstract boolean performEquals(Object o1,
                                       Object o2)
This method must be overridden by subclasses to define the way to compare two keys for equality.

Parameters:
o1 - an object to compare
o2 - the object to compare o1 to
Returns:
true if the two objects should be considered equal in the eyes of the set
performHashCode 
 public abstract int performHashCode(Object key)
This method must be overridden by subclasses to define the way to get a hashCode for a key.

Parameters:
key - the (possibly potential) key whose hashCode is desired
Returns:
the hashCode of the key
